Additional forms: Also Parjialṭ-to be twined around;alṭayp-(alṭayt-) to wind round (tr.)
Notes: In DEDR Salurall-is separately placed in entry 260 as 'to twine' and entry 207 as 'to spread as a creeper'.
Loss of final-lin several Kolami dialects is absotely regular.

Additional forms: Also Kolamiaṭip-(aṭipt-) to stick (tr.), put (child) to breast; Naikriaṭip-to stick (tr.)
Also Kolami_SRtaŋgodāwife's elder sister; Naikritaŋgoḍalwife's elder sister; Naikitaŋgodahusband's elder sister; (?) Gadba_S3naggalwife's younger sister
Also Kolami_SRrāp-to fell; Naikrirālp-to make to fall out
Also Kolamibatkip-(batkipt-) to rear; Naikribadkip-to make to live, bring up

Notes: The nasal cluster is unconfirmed by external data; possibly due to contamination with*gamp-'basket'.

Additional forms: Also Kolamigogip-(gogipt-) to make to bend over, bend (tr.) at a sharp angle; Naikrikoŋkicurved hoe; Parjikokoroa curl;koktacrooked, zigzag;kokṛ-,kokṛayt-to contract (arm, etc.)

Word: ḍig-, dig- "to descend, come down from a height"
Additional forms: Also Kolamidip-(dipt-),digip-(digipt-) to make to come down from a height; Naikriḍipp-to make to descend; Naikiḍigap-,ḍigup-/ḍigp-to make to descend; Parjiiṛkip-(iṛkit-) to make to descend, put down (burden); Ollariiṛigp-(iṛigt-) to make to descend

Word: in- "to say (so-and-so), be said to be (so-and-so)"

Additional forms: Also Naiki caus.alup-; Parjiaṛtip-(aṛtit-) to cause to weep or cry; Ollariaṛup-(aṛut-) to make to cry
Also (from Glasfurd's: Papers Relating To The Dependency of Bustar, 1863) Parjiyanoo.
Also Naikrikaṭṭabund of field, dam, dike;kaṭṭenecklace; Parjikaḍk-to tie, fasten, bind;kaṭṭabund of field; Salurgaṭṭubank
Notes: Salurgaṭṭuis probably (if it is not borrowed) the only surviving form of*gaṭ-'dam', which has become totally contaminated with*kaṭ-in PKG.
We probably have to deal with two different roots here, since there is no way to explain the correspondence Kolami, Naiki-e-- Parji-i-(and there are differences in semantics as well).

Additional forms: Also Parjikicc-to pluck (strings of instrument with finger)

Notes: Since there are no contradicting data from Parji-Gadba (where the resonant is usually preserved), an inlaut *-r_- can be supposed.

Additional forms: Also Parjikopp-to be full;kopip-(kopit-) to fill up;kopafull;koppasmall hillock; Ollarikopehill, forest; Gadba_S3kopup-to fill (tr.);koppenfull
Notes: Evidence for two roots here, indeed, confirmed by external data.

Additional forms: Also (?) Gadba_S3maṇ-(maṇḍ-) to turn back (intr.);maṇp-(maṇup-) id. (tr.)
Also Kolamimarndal(pl.-dasil) mother's brother's daughter; Kolami_SRmarāndāwife's younger sister
Also Parjimed-to flash (tiger's eye, etc.); Salurmerslightning
Also Naikimuyip-to cover oneself, fill up a hole; Parjimuypip-(muypit-) to cover (another);muccashell-covering of the snail
Also Naikrinaṛmutin the middle; Naikiaḍmunin the middle; Parjinaṛbulin the middle

Also Kolami_SRsegurfive persons; Parjiceyalfive women;cē̃du(k) five things; adj.cem/n

Notes: Irregularc-in Salur. The form may be borrowed from Telugu.
Kolami forms are eventually re-borrowings from Telugu. This is proved a) by initial zero, which is never observed in Kolami; b) by-r(*-dwould be expected).

Additional forms: Also Kolamisasi-(sasit-) to leave (say-+sī-to give); Parji (S)cāypip-(cāypit-) to cause to leave, wean; Gadba_S3sāyupp-to heal a wound
